docs.abstract: Photo of General Motors Corp's chief executive Rick Wagoner, who outlines plan with UAW to cut health benefits to company's retirees
docs.snippet: Photo of General Motors Corp's chief executive Rick Wagoner, who outlines plan with UAW to cut health benefits to company's retirees

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman whose family said she heard voices that told her to dump her three young children into the frigid waters of San Francisco Bay was charged Thursday with three counts of murder. The mother, Lashaun T. Harris, 23, of Oakland, has been in custody since Wednesday in the killings of the children, identified by the police as Treyshun Harris, 6; Taronta Greeley, 2; and Joshoa Greeley, 16 months.

headline.main: Woman Charged in Deaths of Her 3 Children

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 - A woman whose family said she heard voices that told her to dump her three young children into the frigid waters of San Francisco Bay was charged Thursday with three counts of murder.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cadillac of health care plans is being traded in. The United Automobile Workers on Thursday announced the details of its tentative agreement with General Motors to impose health benefit cuts on union retirees. For the first time, G.M. retirees will have to pay deductibles, monthly premiums and co-payments for services like X-rays.

headline.main: Union Offers Details of Health Deal With G.M.

docs.abstract: United Automobile Workers announces details of its tentative agreement with General Motors to impose health benefit cuts on union retirees; GM retirees will have to pay deductibles, monthly premiums and co-payments for services like X-rays for first time; retired GM worker could pay as much as $370 a year for traditional coverage, option most retirees favor; retired family could pay as much as $752; they now pay nothing for coverage; active workers are also being asked to make their own concessions by giving up $1 an hour in 2006 by deferring cost-of-living adjustments and planned wage increases; money will be contributed to fund created to help pay retiree medical costs; photo of UAW president Ron Gettelfinger and negotiator Richard Shoemaker (M)
docs.snippet: For the first time, General Motors retirees will have to pay deductibles, monthly premiums and co-payments for services like X-rays.

byline.original: By DANNY HAKIM and JEREMY W. PETERS

docs.lead_paragraph: The emerging technique of using stents to open carotid arteries in the neck can be successfully performed by even doctors with limited experience in the procedure, if they receive training, according to preliminary results of a federally mandated study released Thursday. That finding, as well as results reported on Wednesday from a separate study of carotid stents, could encourage regulators to expand Medicare coverage for the procedure, according to doctors involved in the studies. The federal government has estimated that as many as 200,000 Americans undergo carotid-clearing surgery each year. Regulators approved marketing the stents to a high-risk group that could include as many as 25 percent of those people, but Medicare is covering fewer than 10 percent of them.

headline.main: Report on Stents Could Spur Increase in Medicare Aid

docs.abstract: Preliminary results of federally mandated study, sponsored by Guidant, show emerging technique of using stents to open carotid arteries in neck can be successfully performed by even doctors with limited experience in procedure; that finding, as well as results reported from separate Johnson & Johnson study of carotid stents, could encourage regulators to expand Medicare coverage for procedure (M)
docs.snippet: According to a study, the technique of using stents to open carotid arteries in the neck can be successfully performed by even doctors with limited experience in the procedure.

docs.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of General Motors, addressing the anxiety of auto workers over cuts in benefits, said Wednesday that he and other executives would receive less compensation this year, a result of the company's financial troubles. The chief, Rick Wagoner, said G.M's top five executives would see their compensation fall this year by at least 40 percent because much of it is tied to bonuses and incentives.

headline.main: Chief Says Pay at Top of G.M. Will Be Less

docs.abstract: General Motors Corp's chief executive Rick Wagoner, addressing anxiety of auto workers over cuts in benefits, says his compensation and that of four other top executives will fall by at least 40 percent because much of it is tied to bonuses and incentives (S)
docs.snippet: DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP) - The chief executive of General Motors, addressing the anxiety of auto workers over cuts in benefits, said Wednesday that he and other executives would receive less compensation this year, a result of the company's financial...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''This country is in one heck of a mess.'' If there is a single sentiment members of Congress heard while back in their districts this month, that was it.
docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column says despite fact that anger at Pres Bush among many Americans is so deep, Republicans in Congress are not panicking over midterm elections because because even Democratic partisans describe their own party as 'pathetic'; says nation can expect an ideas race in next weeks, as both parties hustle to get out new, positive agendas; says Democrats will continue to offer everything to everybody, while Republicans, who sense that people are exhausted by big visions and grand dreams, will end up localizing the elections (M)
docs.snippet: Over the next weeks, we are going to see an ideas race, as both parties hustle to get out new, positive agendas.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Tax Advisers to Bush Prepare 2 Overhaul Plans That Will Take Aim at Popular Breaks'' (news article, Oct. 19):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:      Re ''Tax Advisers to Bush Prepare 2 Overhaul Plans That Will Take Aim at Popular Breaks'' (news article, Oct. 19):

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration approved a sweeping Medicaid plan for Florida on Wednesday that limits spending for many of the 2.2million beneficiaries there and gives private health plans new freedom to limit benefits. The Florida program, likely to be a model for many other states, shifts from the traditional Medicaid ''defined benefit'' plan to a ''defined contribution'' plan, under which the state sets a ceiling on spending for each recipient.

headline.main: U.S. GIVES FLORIDA A SWEEPING RIGHT TO CURB MEDICAID

docs.abstract: Bush administration approves sweeping Medicaid plan for Florida that limits spending for many of 2.2 million beneficiaries there and gives private health plans new freedom to limit benefits; Florida program is likely to be model for many other states; it sets ceiling on spending for each recipient, except for children under age of 21 and pregnant women; Health and Human Services Dept Sec Michael O Leavitt approves proposal 16 days after it is formally submitted to him; it has strong support of Gov Jeb Bush, who has called current form of Medicaid unsustainable; Pres Bush has proposed similar changes at federal level for several years, but Democrats and some moderate Republicans in Congress have resisted, saying it would allow states to reduce coverage for very poor and very sick; Leavitt has waived many provisions of federal law, letting Florida make changes in demonstration project (M)
docs.snippet: The plan limits spending for many of Florida's 2.2 million beneficiaries and gives private health plans freedom to limit benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's tax advisory commission agreed on Tuesday to recommend two alternative plans, both of which would limit or eliminate almost all existing tax deductions, including those for state and local income and property taxes. The recommendations, due to be submitted to the president by Nov. 1, were designed so that the tax burdens borne by the rich, the middle class and the poor would be roughly the same as now.

headline.main: Tax Advisers to Bush Prepare 2 Overhaul Plans That Will Take Aim at Popular Breaks

docs.snippet: The two plans would limit or end almost all tax deductions, including ones for state and local income and property taxes.

docs.lead_paragraph: American corporations have to run leaner and meaner in the global competitive environment. By agreeing to let General Motors trim the well-above-average health benefits it offers, the United Auto Workers negotiators showed that they are willing to be active participants, rather than merely speed bumps, on the road to globalization. We hope that rank-and-file union members approve the deal, trusting that accepting less now may mean more later on. The compromise will save G.M. $1 billion annually in health costs for workers, retirees and their families -- money the company desperately needs, having lost nearly $4 billion in this year alone.
docs.abstract: Editorial praises UAW for agreeing to health benefit cuts to help General Motors compete in global market, noting that reduced benefits will probably still be superior to what most Americans have; adds that GM still has to make cars people want to buy and still has to compete with countries like Japan and Germany that have national health care
docs.snippet: Lawmakers need to get it through their heads that health care reform isn't about handouts as much as competitiveness.
